The fourth part of the chapter on wisdom in the Abhidharma, the remaining part of the chapter on the cultivation of wisdom: How does one not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of suffering?
Answer:

When practicing the knowledge of the law of practice, the knowledge of the unknown of practice, the knowledge of the law of exhaustion, the knowledge of the unknown of exhaustion, the knowledge of the law of the path, the traces of learning seen, or when an arhat originally attains the knowledge of no outflows and it is present, this is not the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of suffering;
When originally attaining the knowledge of the world and it is present, this is not the knowledge of others' minds;
If one originally does not attain the knowledge of the world and it is present, at that time one does not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of suffering.

All those who do not know the minds of others, ordinary people with defiled minds, indeterminate minds, those who enter the concentration of non-perception, the concentration of cessation, the gods of non-perception, and all those who have patience present do not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of suffering.
This is called not cultivating the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of suffering.
If one cultivates the knowledge of others' minds at that time, does one also cultivate the knowledge of practice?
Answer:
One may cultivate the knowledge of others' minds without cultivating the knowledge of practice.
How does one cultivate the knowledge of others' minds without cultivating the knowledge of practice?
Answer:

Ordinary people who have attained or have not attained the knowledge of others' minds manifest it, or if the knowledge of worldly matters that has not been attained previously manifests, and it is not the knowledge of others' minds, at that time one cultivates the knowledge of others' minds.
Learners who have seen the truths, or arhats, who have previously attained the knowledge of others' minds manifest it.
This is called cultivating the knowledge of others' minds without cultivating the knowledge of practice.
How does one cultivate the knowledge of practice without cultivating the knowledge of others' minds?
Answer:

When practicing the Dharma knowledge of practice, the unknown knowledge of practice, and the knowledge of others' minds, when practicing the path unknown knowledge of the learned who have seen the traces, or when an arhat previously attained the knowledge of practice and it is present, or when previously unattained pure knowledge is present, at that time one does not cultivate the knowledge of others' minds;
if previously unattained worldly knowledge is present, at that time one cultivates the knowledge of practice but not the knowledge of others' minds.
This is called cultivating the knowledge of practice but not the knowledge of others' minds.
What is meant by cultivating the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of practice?
Answer:

When the knowledge of others' minds is practiced, when practicing the path unknown knowledge of the learned who have seen the traces, or when an arhat previously did not attain worldly knowledge or pure knowledge and it is present, at that time one cultivates the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of practice. This is called cultivating the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of practice.
What is meant by not cultivating the knowledge of others' minds and the knowledge of practice?
Answer:

If one cultivates the cognition of dharmas regarding suffering, the cognition of subsequent knowledge regarding suffering, the cognition of exhaustion regarding cessation, the cognition of subsequent knowledge regarding exhaustion, the cognition of the dharma regarding the path, the view of the trace of learning, or if one is an arhat who has attained the uncontaminated cognition and it is present, this is not the cognition of others' minds;
If one has not previously attained and now manifests the mundane cognition, at that time one does not cultivate the cognition of others' minds and the cognition of elimination;

All those who do not have the cognition of others' minds, ordinary people with defiled minds and indeterminate minds, those who enter the concentration of non-perception, the concentration of cessation, and the heaven of non-perception, all of whom have patience present, do not cultivate the cognition of others' minds and the cognition of elimination.
This is called not cultivating the cognition of others' minds and the cognition of elimination.
